options.label: A
options.text: The mother and fetus share the same genes

options.label: B
options.text: The fetus inherits genes from its father that promote its own survival

options.label: C
options.text: The mother wants to provide equally for all her offspring

options.label: D
options.text: The fetus wants to provide equally for all its siblings

multiple-choice.question: In most mammals, what is the function of the maternal cells surrounding the placenta?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide nutrients to the fetus

options.label: B
options.text: To control the supply of nutrients to the fetus

options.label: C
options.text: To remove waste products from the fetus

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the mother's blood pressure

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a fetus having unrestricted access to the mother's bloodstream?

options.label: A
options.text: The mother's blood sugar decreases

options.label: B
options.text: The mother's arteries constrict

options.label: C
options.text: The mother's blood pressure decreases

options.label: D
options.text: The fetus can manufacture hormones to increase the mother's blood sugar

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult for a human mother to expel or reabsorb an embryo?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the placenta is confined behind a barrier of maternal cells

options.label: B
options.text: Because the fetus is connected to the mother's blood supply

options.label: C
options.text: Because the embryo is too large

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mother's immune system is weakened

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the endometrium making implantation difficult for an embryo?

options.label: A
options.text: To select for the most vigorously invasive embryos

options.label: B
options.text: To provide nutrients to the embryo

options.label: C
options.text: To remove waste products from the embryo

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the mother's blood pressure

multiple-choice.question: What happens to an embryo that fails to implant in the endometrium?

options.label: A
options.text: It is removed from the womb through menstruation

options.label: B
options.text: It continues to grow and develop

options.label: C
options.text: It is reabsorbed by the mother's body

options.label: D
options.text: It causes infection in the mother

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of menstruation in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide nutrients to the embryo

options.label: B
options.text: To remove waste products from the embryo

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the mother's blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: To remove the endometrial lining and any unfertilized eggs or dead embryos

multiple-choice.question: Why is pregnancy considered a huge and sometimes dangerous investment for a mother?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the fetus provides nutrients to the mother

options.label: B
options.text: Because the mother's immune system is weakened

options.label: C
options.text: Because the fetus's ongoing need for resources can cause intense fatigue and health complications

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mother's blood pressure decreases

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of the biological process of menstruation?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: To promote the spread of genes

options.label: C
options.text: To remove waste products from the body

options.label: D
options.text: To set the course for the continuation of the human race
